Factor out common terms if any.
Consider x=0 as a potential solution and verify if it satisfies the equation.
Examine the equation for patterns such as symmetry or repeating coefficients that may suggest substitution or further simplification.
Explore possible rational roots using the rational root theorem.
Use synthetic division to test potential roots identified from the rational root theorem.
If a root is found, factor the polynomial through polynomial division and look for further solutions.
After factoring, solve any lower degree polynomial equations that are identified.
Analyze the remaining polynomial for irreducibility. If the polynomial cannot be factored further using elementary methods, consider numerical methods or special factorizations.
If higher degree polynomials remain (greater than degree four), consider numerical techniques or graphing methods to approximate or visually identify roots.
Verify all found solutions by substituting them back into the original equation.
